column1: Ancud (Spanish pronunciation: [aŋˈkuð]) is a city in southern Chile located in the northernmost part of the island and province of Chiloé
column2: in Los Lagos Region. It is the second largest city of Chiloé Archipelago after Castro. The city was established in 1768 to function as the capital of the archipelago and held that position until 1982. Founded as bulwark against foreign powers in colonial times
column3: the city played an important role in the Chilean colonization of Patagonia in the 19th century.

column1: Numerous glaciations have dredged the Chacao Channel to the north
column2: separating Chiloé Island from mainland Chile to the north
column3: marking the border between two natural regions of Chile
column4: Zona Sur to the north and Zona Austral to the south. The Pacific Ocean lies on the west as the Chilean Coastal Range continues as a chain of islands. To the southeast of the commune is Quemchi and Dalcahue to the south. The commune has a surface area of 1
column5: 752.4 km2 (677 sq mi). To the west are the coastal villages of Pumillahue and Quetalmahue
column6: among others. 25 kilometers west of Ancud lies Islotes de Puñihuil Natural Monument
column7: a group of preserved islands that provide habitat to various penguin species.

column1: Prior to its establishment as a Spanish settlement the site of Ancud was known as Puerto Inglés (lit. English port). It was on here that Hendrik Brouwer
column2: the leader of the Dutch expedition to Valdivia died on August 7
column4: before reaching Valdivia.As consequence of the Seven Years' War the Spanish authorities had the coastal fortification system of Chile updated and expanded. Inspired in the recommendations of former governor Antonio Narciso de Santa María
column5: the Spanish  founded the "city-fort" of Ancud in 1767–1768 and separated Chiloé from the Captaincy General of Chile into a direct dependency of the Viceroyalty of Peru. As with other 18th-century forts in Chile
column6: the establishment of Ancud led through the new Ancud-Castro road to an expansion on local trade and agriculture.

column1: Ancud has an oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification Cfb) with significant precipitation in each month. Winters are cool and wet with a July average of 7.5 °C (45.5 °F). Precipitation during this time of the year is very high
column2: averaging around 350 millimetres (14 in) and humidity is high
column3: averaging around 87-88%. Summers are mild with a January average of 15.0 °C (59.0 °F) and during this time
column4: precipitation is lower though still significant
column5: averaging 125 millimetres (5 in) in January. Temperatures rarely exceed 30 °C (86.0 °F). The average annual precipitation is 2
column6: 540 millimetres (100 in) and there are 200 days with measureable precipitation. However
column7: precipitation is highly variable from year to year with 1993 being the driest
column8: recording only 759 millimetres (30 in) and 1977 being the wettest at 3
column9: 712 millimetres (146 in). The record high was 32.7 °C (90.9 °F) on January 27
column11: and the record low was −3.0 °C (26.6 °F) on June 30

column10: 430 persons) between the 1992 and 2002 censuses. The demonym of a person from Ancud is Ancuditano for a man and Ancuditana for a woman.

column2: Ancud is a third-level administrative division of Chile administered by a municipal council
column3: headed by an alcalde who is directly elected every four years. The 2008-2012 alcalde is Federico Krüger Finterbüch.Within the electoral divisions of Chile
column4: Ancud is represented in the Chamber of Deputies by Mr. Gabriel Ascencio (PDC) and Mr. Alejandro Santana (RN) as part of the 58th electoral district
column16: Futaleufú and Palena). The commune is represented in the Senate by Camilo Escalona Medina (PS) and Carlos Kuschel Silva (RN) as part of the 17th senatorial constituency (Los Lagos Region).

column1: Previously the area had a German school

The fort system of Ancud together with nearby the forts of Agüi one of the four fort systems that existed in colonial Chiloé. The fort system of Ancud is made up of two forts and four batteries. Fuerte Real de San Carlos was built as late as 1824 by orders of Antonio de Quintanilla
column2: the last Spanish governor of Chiloé. The arsenal (polvorín) of this can still be seen at the centre of a small plaza. The battery of San Antonio is the best preserved part of the fort system.
